Pretty sure Scott Manley did a video on the radio beeps.

If I recall correctly they originally were required because the radio link could only support telemetry or radio at a time not both. So the beep was to direct the telecommunications equipment to flip back and forth from radio to telemetry.

It was removed in the shuttle era. When technology meant the relays didn't need to be triggered anymore as there was now the bandwidth to do radio and telemetry concurrently. But crews had grown used to it and used it for cueing their transmissions, so NASA put it back in artificially on purpose!

I would love for an Everyday Astronaut fan who works at SpaceX MCC to throw in a "Norminal" once or twice over the radio for you Tim.

The caution around the detected vapors seems excessive seeing as there were at least 8 ground crew outside the vehicle wearing various respirators and flimsy face masks,... and that the astronauts are wearing friggin space suits. They could easily either don the same respirators as the ground crew OR attach some filter/O2 to their space suits. Honestly, given how that thing blew up once before, I'd be keen to get ground crew and astronauts away from it ASAP. Just have the astronauts wear their helmets for a few minutes during egress.

HELL IF SPACEX DYNAMIC DUO OF BATMAN AND ROBIN, DOUG AND BOB MADE IT AS ASTRONAUTS TO FLY INTO SPACE BASED ON THEIR AGE; THEN SHOOT I STILL GOT A SHOT TO MAKE IT AS A ASTRONAUT AS WELL. DOUG AND BOB ARE MY NEW HEROES AT COURSE AFTER MY FIRST HEROE MY OWN COUNTRY MEN COSTA RICA'S VERY BEST ASTRONAUT FRANKLING CHANG DIAZ; BUT DOUG AND BOB ARE DEFINITELY MY NEW HEROES AND INSPIRATION FOR US OLDER GUYS AND GIRLS, AS WELL AS THE YOUNG. HATS OFF THOUGH TO ELON MUSK, FOR THINKING OUTSIDE THE BOX, AND HAVING A VISION OF HOW THINGS SHOULD BE DONE TRAVELING INTO SPACE, NOW AND IN THE FUTURE. ELON  AND I SEE THINGS VERY SIMILAR, NO WONDER THEY SAY THAT GREAT MINDS THINK ALIKE, INSTEAD OF WORKING OR DOING THINGS HARDER, WHY NOT DO IT SMARTER. YEARS BACK WITH VIRGIN GALACTICA PROJECT, I HAD APPLIED BUT NO LUCK; THEN CAME PROJECT MARS ONE TO GO TO MARS, AND AS ALWAYS I GOT BAD LUCK; SO MARS ONE TEAM TRY TO GET A HOLD OF ME VIA EMAIL AND WAS EVEN GIVING ME EXTRA TIME TO SUBMIT MY 6 ANSWERS TO THEIR QUESTIONS. BUT AT THE TIME I HAD NO PHONE I BELIEVE, AND AT THE TIME MY LAPTOP WAS IN A PAWN SHOP; SO BY THE TIME I WAS ABLE TO GET MY LAPTOP OUT OF THE PAWNSHOP, THE DEADLINE MARS ONE HAD GIVING ME HAD EXPIRED, SO SO MUCH TO GOING TO MARS. NOW WITH THIS SPACEX MISSION WITH  DOUG AND BOB WITH THEIR SUCCESS, LIKE I SAID I STILL GOT HOPE BASED ON MY AGE TO ONE DAY BECOMING AN ASTRONAUT AND TRAVEL INTO SPACE. HATS OFF TO EVERYONE THAT WAS PART OF THIS MISSION AND FUTURE MISSIONS; FROM THE ENGINEERS, MECHANICS, MISSION CONTROL, THE MODERATORS OR HOST AND HOSTESS OF SPACEX YOUTUBE CHANNEL, THE RECOVERY TEAM, EVERYONE THAT CHIPPED IN; HAIL, HAIL SPACEX FOR THIS SUCCESSFUL MISSION AND MANY MORE TO COME, I AM YOUR NUMBER ONE FAN. PURA VIDA. even the recovery of the Orion MPCV test vehicle in 2014 was still recovered by the USS America LHA-6 (not exactly an aircraft carrier but same size as a US WWII aircraft carrier, and they were not that far off into blue water. I believe they were just a couple hundred miles off the San Diego coast. I just think this is more evidence that NASA is like any government bureau, not capable of making quick efficient choices or changes as needed. That's why NASAs idea of a really big spaceship hasn't changed since W. Van Braun. Thank god for the switch to private companies to lead our space efforts. Now if Boeing can only get it's act together and put engineers back in charge they may have a chance of survival.

Tim,

As always I join your stream because I learn something new each time! You create such a great event regardless of what’s happening. Agree with your view about ‘Team Space’ where it’s all about humanity and exploration.

I watched the SpaceX stream on another system while listening/watching your stream. Listen to the closing statements from the announcers. The SpaceX employee starts to get choked up talking about the commitment to their mission. I don’t know about the rest of you, but I can get choked up watching a launch because the amount of dedication and work is off the charts. I admire and envy SpaceX employees. Hope they all feel this way when they see the results of all their individual efforts towards the end result. Elon has made our ‘trampoline’ something the world only wishes they could do. So if there is a more than a bit of National Pride in my tone, I will own that too.

Kudos to NASA, SpaceX and people such as yourself for making this all happen and allowing us to be a witness to these historic events. Without your enthusiasm to spread knowledge, we most likely wouldn’t have a glimpse of how tremendous these events and capabilities are to mere mortals.

Today’s success, will only allow more science to occur while travel being less expensive. Also will allow more frequent trips due to reduced cost.

Indeed, this is a great time to be alive despite all the other challenges. Looking forward to September! See you there and along the way...

Launches are impressive....

But isn’t this the first time anywhere and anytime that an average Joe had an opportunity witness a landing by something other than a space shuttle?

Launches?

ahhhh....

.....been there, done that.....


Space shuttle landing?

‘Zipp.... (gone)’ flyby

or

Now......


Parachutes?
Splash Downs?

Wow,,,,,,,,,,,,,,


Now.....

A helicopter could use prop wash to discourage boaters from getting too close to landing zone prior to splash down.

In past Navy had big ‘ol aircraft carrier and several helicopters to discourage anyone who might venture the several hundreds of miles out to sea to what was a perhaps a somewhat discrete location.

Russian and China landings obviously very much no go for civilians.

When Starship lands, there would be the beginnings of a lucrative tourist industry if launches and landings of Falcon, Starships and other spacecraft occur at same ‘Space Facility’ (Cape Canaveral) every week or so.

Stay well.....


Dreaming........

Landing of a Starship should be super duper impressive.

Spacex could build a special blockhouse for several hundred big ticket tourists to witness both launches and landings of Starship from close at hand at the Space facility.

Blockhouse would be located far enough for.....

..... explosive actuated blast shields that activate to cover thick shock resistant windows prior to arrival of a potential shock wave.

I can imagine an immensely expensive 20 or more channel sound system to replicate external sound inside blockhouse with hydraulic actuators slaved to sensors mounted on launch and landing pads to literally ‘shake’ the floor for an added effect.

Observation block house would be equipped to be self sufficient in case access were temporarily denied by some catastrophic event.

Just dreaming.....

BTW:
How much do you think one might pay to personally witness close hand an experience like that?

watching your coverage after the fact! Thanks for that. It seems to me future recoveries should be accompanied by the Coast Guard. funny thought, several of the early cosmonauts were greeted by farmers upon landing! Gagarin and Leonov to name a few.

Adiabatic compression. Take a bicycle pump as well as a wheel and pick a place out of the sun with a stable temperature and wait for them to reach equilibrium. Now pump up the tyre! You will now be able to note them the pump is a lot warmer than it started, the tyre should be a little as well. This is not down to friction, but adiabatic compression. It is the same effect a space vehicle encounters on reentry as the air cannot get out of the way fast enough and is compressed instead...
